JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Päivi Hirvelä;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , together with CARDINAL other persons , was questioned by the police as a suspect in a forgery that allegedly took place in DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE charges were brought against the applicant . A hearing before the GPE ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tinsgrätten ) was scheduled for CARDINAL DATE but it was cancelled due to the absence of CARDINAL codefendants .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE ORG convicted the applicant of aiding and abetting forgery and sentenced him to pay CARDINAL dayfines , in total CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE the applicant appealed to ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätten ) , requesting that his sentence be mitigated due to the excessive length of the proceedings . Subsequently , the applicant also claimed compensation under LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld ORG conviction but decided not to impose any sentence on the applicant . It found that there was reason to mitigate the sentence as a considerably long period had passed since the commission of the offence . As to compensation , the court found that the mitigation of the sentence in itself was a sufficient remedy and that the applicant could therefore not be granted any monetary compensation under LAW .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter dated DATE the applicant appealed to ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) , claiming that mitigation of the sentence was not sufficient compensation for the excessive length of proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused the applicant leave to appeal .
CARDINAL . According to LAW , section CARDINAL , of LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflagen ; as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ,
“ [ ORG addition to what is provided above in LAW , grounds mitigating the punishment that are also to be taken into consideration are ;

( CARDINAL ) a considerably long period that has passed since the commission of the offence ; if the punishment that accords with established practice would for these reason lead to an unreasonable or exceptionally detrimental result . ”

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE ( GPE ) ORG noted that , although there were no legal provisions justifying the dismissal of a criminal charge due to unreasonably lengthy proceedings , such a dismissal or declaring a case inadmissible might in some exceptional circumstances , for example if their duration ruled out a good defence , be the only effective remedy satisfying the requirements of LAW . That was , however , not so in that precedent case . In considering whether there were grounds for applying LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW , ORG held that it had to be decided in PERSON whether the duration of the proceedings ( in the precedent case over DATE ) had been unreasonable . It concluded that in that case there were no grounds to waive a sentence or to mitigate the sentence owing to the duration of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . NORP In its judgment of DATE ( PERSON ) , ORG , applying LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW , reduced the sentence imposed upon the applicant by DATE owing to the length of the proceedings that had lasted DATE . The court imposed an immediate term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , finding that it was not justifiable to mitigate the sentence further by suspending the term of imprisonment .

CARDINAL . The Act on Compensation for Excessive Duration of Judicial Proceedings ( laki oikeudenkäynnin viivästymisen hyvittämisestä , lagen om gottgörelse för dröjsmål vid rättegång ; Act no . ORG ) entered into force on DATE . The LAW provides for a party a right to receive compensation from ORG funds whenever judicial proceedings concerning that party have been excessively long .
CARDINAL . According to LAW , sections CARDINAL , of LAW ,
“ LAW of day fines ( PERSON )
A fine shall be passed as day fines , the minimum number of which is one and the maximum number is CARDINAL .
Section CARDINAL - Amount of a day fine ( CARDINAL/CARDINAL )
The amount of a day fine shall be set so that it is reasonable in view of the solvency of the person fined .

CARDINAL sixtieth of the average DATE income of the person fined , less the taxes and fees defined by a Decree and a fixed deduction for basic consumption , is deemed to be a reasonable amount of DATE fine . The maintenance liability of the person fined may decrease DATE fine .

The primary basis for the calculation of the DATE income is the income of the person fined as indicated in the most recent taxation . If the income of the person fined can not be reliably ascertained from the tax records or it has essentially changed since the most recent taxation , it may be assessed also on the basis of other information .
Section CARDINAL - Total amount of the fine ( CARDINAL )
The total amount of the fine is equal to the number of day fines times the amount of DATE fine .
CARDINAL . Chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL , of the same PERSON provides the following :
“ Section CARDINAL - Passing a conversion sentence ( CARDINAL/CARDINAL )

A person who has been sentenced to a fine and from whom the collection of the fine has failed , shall be ordered to imprisonment in lieu of the unpaid fine . A conversion sentence shall be passed for an unpaid threat of a fine , the collection of which has failed , if the court has imposed it in order to ensure the conduct of court proceedings or pursuant to LAW ( CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . Any other threat of fine may not be converted into imprisonment . ”
